1. Can UXP plugins access and manipulate audio data directly from timeline clips, or do I need to export audio to a temp file first?
2. What Premiere Pro APIs are available for modifying clip labels, colors, and markers programmatically via UXP?

For each question provide:
- A direct answer if you find it
- Links to official docs, tutorials, or repos with the answer
- Code examples that illustrate the concept

Search for:
- Adobe Premiere Pro UXP API documentation
- Premiere Pro ExtendScript vs UXP capabilities
- Premiere Pro clip manipulation API
- Premiere Pro marker API UXP
- Premiere Pro audio access API

Focus on finding actual API methods and code examples from Adobe's official documentation or reliable GitHub repos.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP audio access API for timeline clips:

## Premiere Pro UXP API Overview

Premiere adds its own APIs on top of the base UXP functionality.(no content)The API allows access to sequences, tracks, clips, markers, project items, and application settings.

## API Capabilities

Premiere APIs, also called DOM APIs, give you direct access to Premiere's document model. These APIs let you access and modify projects — sequences, tracks, clips, and markers; work with media — import files, manage project items; control playback — set in/out points, control the playhead; and apply effects — add video and audio effects to clips.

## Audio and Timeline Clip Manipulation

While exploring the documentation, developers have found classes like Sequence, ClipProjectItem, and AudioClipTrackItem, but some have had difficulty identifying clear ways to accomplish certain tasks programmatically.(no content)The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin shows how to clone and remove track items. For audio clips, you can use the `moveToTrack` method on QETrackItem objects, with parameters for video track movement, audio track movement, timecode, and copy/move options.

## Current Limitations

UXP in Premiere Pro is very new so lots of APIs haven't been built yet. If you need a production panel today or in the near future, you may need to build it in CEP.(no content)The QE DOM APIs remain available but are "100% unsupported, and not at all recommended."

## Migration Status

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

## Resources

- The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.
- Adobe provides a third-party sample panel called 'premiere-api' available from the uxp-premiere-pro-samples Git repository.

Based on my search, here's what I found about Adobe Premiere Pro UXP plugin API documentation:

## Adobe Premiere Pro UXP Plugin API Documentation

### Official Documentation
The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.

### Key Updates for 2024-2025

UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform) has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6. This release represents a major step forward in modernizing the extensibility ecosystem.(no content)UXP is the next generation of APIs, for Premiere v25.6 and beyond.

### What is UXP?

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level. With UXP, you can build unique tools that integrate with and optimize the most precise, demanding workflows.

### API Architecture

The platform includes two main API types: UXP Core APIs for building user interfaces, file operations, network calls, and general functionality, and Premiere APIs for interacting with and modifying Premiere projects and sequences. Most often you will need to use both APIs together to create the functionality you want.(no content)Premiere version (v25.6) determines which Premiere DOM APIs are available, while UXP version (v8.1) determines which UXP Core APIs are available. Each Premiere release integrates a specific UXP version—for example, Premiere v25.6 includes UXP v8.1.

### Getting Started

Before you start, make sure you have Premiere (v25.6) or later, UXP Developer Tool (v2.2) or later, and a code editor of your choice—for example, Visual Studio Code or Cursor.(no content)The UXP Developer Tool (UDT) simplifies the process of creating, loading, managing, and debugging plugins for Adobe's UXP-powered applications. UXP plugins are supported in Premiere v25.6 and later since UDT v2.2.

### Resources

- **Main documentation**: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- **API Reference**: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/
- **Sample SDK**: https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.

Here are the search results for Premiere Pro UXP clip markers labels colors API:

## Overview

Premiere adds its own APIs on top of the base UXP functionality.(no content)The API allows you to access sequences, tracks, clips, markers, project items, and application settings.

## Color Labels API

The UXP API provides methods for working with color labels on project items:

`getColorLabelIndex(): Promise<number>` - Get color label index of projectItem(no content)`createSetColorLabelAction(inColorLabelIndex: number): Action` - Create an action for set color label to projectItem by index

For the legacy ExtendScript API, `app.project.rootItem.children[index].getColorLabel()` retrieves the project item's color label. And `app.project.rootItem.children[index].setColorLabel(labelColor)` sets the project item's color label.

## Markers API

`getMarkers(markerOwnerObject: Sequence | ClipProjectItem): Promise<Markers>` - Returns the Markers object for Sequence Or ProjectItem(no content)`createAddMarkerAction(Name: string, markerType?: string, startTime?: TickTime, duration?: TickTime, comments?: string): Action` - Add a new marker(no content)`createSetColorByIndexAction(colorIndex: number): Action` - Return an action to set the color of the marker by the color index

## Important Limitations

In PPro, all markers and metadata associated with trackItems are actually attached to the backing projectItem; it's not possible to have different markers and metadata for each trackItem.(no content)Extensions usability is limited by the Adobe Premiere API. For instance, only items that have a source can be labeled, such as video, image, and sound layers.

## API Access

Premiere APIs, also called DOM APIs, give you direct access to Premiere's document model. These APIs let you access and modify projects — sequences, tracks, clips, and markers, work with media, control playback, and apply effects.(no content)The line `require('premierepro')` allows you access to the Premiere DOM via UXP.

## Resources

- The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform).
- ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

content.content: Prompt is too long
Prompt is too long

# Premiere Pro UXP API TypeScript Type Definitions

Based on the GitHub repository content, here are the key TypeScript types related to audio, clips, markers, and colors:

## Audio Types
- **AudioClipTrackItem**: Represents audio clips with methods for speed, in/out points, and component chains
- **AudioTrack**: Manages audio tracks with mute state, media type, and track items retrieval
- **AudioComponentChain**: Handles audio filter components with insert/append/remove actions
- **AudioFilterComponent** & **AudioFilterFactory**: Create and manage audio filters

## Clip & Track Item Types
- **VideoClipTrackItem**: Video equivalent with transition support
- **ClipProjectItem**: Media file representation with proxy, LUT, and interpretation settings
- **TrackItemSelection**: Container for selected track items with add/remove methods

## Marker & Color Types
- **Marker**: Includes name, duration, comments, URL, and type (Comment, Chapter, FlvCuePoint, WebLink)
- **Markers**: Collection methods for adding, moving, and removing markers
- **MarkerColor enum**: GREEN, RED, MAGENTA, ORANGE, YELLOW, BLUE, CYAN

## Label & Organization
- **ProjectItemColorLabel enum**: 15 color labels (VIOLET, IRIS, LAVENDER, CERULEAN, FOREST, ROSE, MANGO, PURPLE, BLUE, TEAL, MAGENTA, TAN, GREEN, BROWN, YELLOW)

## Audio Access Methods
Audio data access occurs through component parameters supporting "keyframes, time-varying values, and interpolation modes" across audio filter chains.

content.content:
# UXP Premiere Pro Sample Plugins

Based on the repository content, there is **one main sample plugin** available:

## Premier-API Sample Panel

**Location:** `sample-panels/premiere-api/html/`

**Description:** This is Adobe's third-party sample panel demonstrating UXP plugin development for Premiere Pro.

### Key Features:
- Showcases Premiere Pro UXP API capabilities
- Includes TypeScript definitions for API autocomplete in VS Code
- Contains a transcript JSON definition specification in the assets directory

### Notable Content:
The sample includes `transcript_format_spec.json`, a "Premiere Pro's transcript JSON definition" file, suggesting it covers transcript/caption data handling.

### Building Instructions:
The README specifies: `npm i` followed by `npm run build` generates output in `/build-html`.

**Limitation:** The repository README doesn't explicitly list separate examples for audio access, clip manipulation, markers, or labels as distinct samples. However, since this is a "premiere-api" sample, these capabilities may be integrated within it rather than separated into standalone plugins. No specific code snippets for those features are exposed in the visible documentation.

For detailed API capabilities, Adobe's official documentation is referenced: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/

Based on the search results, here's what I found about exporting audio files/clips programmatically with ExtendScript in Premiere Pro:

## Exporting Audio Clips via ExtendScript

### Key Approaches

1. **Using Export Presets (.epr files)**
   "To export only audio, use an export preset (.epr file) that references an audio-only format. PProPanel shows how to render in PPro instead of AME."

2. **Exporting Selected Audio Clips**
   To export a selected audio clip from a sequence: "Get the sequence selection, set the sequence in/out points to the beginning/end of the trackItem, then render."

### Important Resources

- **PProPanel Sample Code**: The official sample that exercises Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API is available at: https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/tree/master/PProPanel

- **API Capabilities**: "Premiere Pro's ExtendScript-based API allows for broad control of the entire application. ExtendScript can access and manipulate most project elements, including metadata, exporting and rendering options."

### Export Settings Available

The scripting API provides several export-related options:
- "The path to which to export the project and media" and "The path to the output preset (.epr file) to be used."
- "If true, include conformed audio files with exported project."

### Platform Status

"As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP; Unified Extensibility Platform... ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026."

### Workflow for Audio Export

The general workflow involves:
1. Getting the sequence selection
2. Setting sequence in/out points to match the audio clip's start/end times
3. Using an audio-only export preset (.epr file)
4. Rendering either through Premiere Pro directly or via Adobe Media Encoder (AME)

The PProPanel GitHub sample contains working examples of rendering within Premiere Pro without requiring AME.

Based on my search, here's what I found regarding Premiere Pro UXP API and audio waveform/raw audio data access:

## Premiere Pro UXP API Overview

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.(no content)The Unified Extensibility Platform (UXP) has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6. This release represents a major step forward in modernizing the extensibility ecosystem.(no content)As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.

## Audio Waveform Data Access

Regarding raw audio data and waveform access specifically, the search results indicate that this functionality is primarily available through the **C++ SDK** rather than the UXP API:

A separate .pek file is always created. This contains peak audio samples for quick access when Premiere needs to draw the audio waveform, for example in the Source Monitor or Timeline panel. Second, the audio may be conformed into a separate .cfa file.

## Sample Resources

Instructions for developing UXP plugins within Premiere Pro are available on GitHub. As of August 2025, only Premiere Pro BETA builds support UXP plugins. The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.(no content)Adobe has updated their sample code to help developers. The Sample SDK provides practical examples of how to interact with the Premiere API using UXP.

## Key Differences from ExtendScript

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, blocking the UI while executing. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

**Note:** The search results do not show specific UXP API methods for accessing raw audio sample data or waveform data directly. Low-level audio sample access appears to remain in the domain of the C++ SDK for importers and plugins. You may want to check the full Premiere Pro UXP API documentation at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ for any recent additions to audio functionality.

# Premiere Pro Scripting Guide - Audio & Metadata Features

Based on the documentation structure provided, here's what's available:

## Relevant Objects for Your Needs

The guide organizes scripting capabilities into these categories:

**For audio data access:**
- **AudioChannelMapping object** - Found under "Other" section, handles audio channel configuration
- **Encoder object** - Listed under "General," likely manages export/rendering with audio options

**For clip properties (labels/colors):**
- **ProjectItem object** - Described as the main item type for managing project elements
- **TrackItem object** - Handles items on sequences where visual properties would be applied

**For marker work:**
- **Marker object** - Dedicated marker functionality
- **MarkerCollection object** - Batch marker operations

## Important Note

The guide states: "ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026." However, "As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP" for new development.

The documentation doesn't explicitly detail raw audio sample reading methods in this overview. You'd need to consult the specific object documentation pages for detailed method signatures and capabilities.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP `createAddMarkerAction` and Markers:

## Premiere Pro UXP `createAddMarkerAction` API

The `createAddMarkerAction` method signature is:
```typescript
createAddMarkerAction(Name: string, markerType?: string, startTime?: TickTime, duration?: TickTime, comments?: string): Action
```(no content)There's also a `createMoveMarkerAction(marker: Marker, tickTime: TickTime): Action` method to move an existing marker to a new time value.

## Important Usage Notes

When using `createAddMarkerAction`, you need to use `lockedAccess` and `executeTransaction` - these methods are required even when following the documentation correctly for setting up the function itself.(no content)Users have encountered "Script Action failed to execute" errors when trying to use UXP action methods without the proper transaction handling.

## Markers Architecture in Premiere Pro

In Premiere Pro, all markers and metadata associated with trackItems are actually attached to the backing projectItem; it's not possible to have different markers and metadata for each trackItem.(no content)The Markers object is available for both Sequences and ProjectItems.

## Official Documentation

The Premiere Pro UXP API provides access to sequences, tracks, clips, markers, project items, and application settings.(no content)As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported through September 2026.

## Resources

- **Official API Docs**: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/markers/
- **TypeScript Definitions**: https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro/blob/main/src/pages/ppro_reference/types.d.ts

Based on my search results, I found information about color label methods in Premiere Pro UXP API. Here's what I found:

## ClipProjectItem and Color Label Methods in Premiere Pro UXP

### UXP API Methods (New API)

In the Premiere Pro UXP API, the `ProjectItem` class includes:
- `getColorLabelIndex(): Promise<number>` - Get color label index of projectItem
- `createSetColorLabelAction(inColorLabelIndex: number): Action` - Create an action for set color label to projectItem by index(no content)The `ProjectItem` class allows you to cast `FolderItem` or `ClipProjectItem` into `ProjectItem` and create an action for setting color label to projectItem by index.

### ClipProjectItem Class

The `ClipProjectItem` class includes properties like:
- Returns true if Premiere Pro can change the path associated with this project item; otherwise returns false
- Indicates whether it is possible to attach a proxy to this project item(no content)The ClipProjectItem API allows for attaching proxy or high resolution footage or replacing footage with methods like `attachProxy()` and `changeMediaPath()`.

### ExtendScript API (Legacy)

In the legacy ExtendScript API, the equivalent methods are:
- `app.project.rootItem.children[index].getColorLabel()` - Retrieves the project item's color label
- `app.project.rootItem.children[index].setColorLabel(labelColor)` - Sets the project item's color label

### Important Notes

For projectItems, you can use `getColorLabel()` / `setColorLabel()`. Note: trackItems created from a projectItem will not have their label color updated; any new trackItems created from those projectItems will get the updated label.(no content)An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, blocking the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

For more details, you can visit the official documentation at:
- https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/clipprojectitem/
- https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/projectitem/

Based on my search, here's what I found about Premiere Pro ExtendScript and audio channel mapping for clip data export:

## Key Findings

### Audio Channel Mapping Property
"The audio channel mapping currently applied to this ProjectItem" is available as an audioChannelMapping object.

### Exporting Audio via ExtendScript
To export only audio, use an export preset (.epr file) that references an audio-only format.(no content)PProPanel shows how to render in PPro instead of AME.

### Exporting Selected Audio Clips
"Is there a way to get start and end points of the selected clip then export only that? Yes; however, what will you do if more than one audio trackItem is selected? Briefly: Get the sequence selection, set the sequence in/out points to the beginning/end of the trackItem, then render."

### Limitations with Audio Data Access
In Premiere Pro ExtendScript, "there is not audio channel data available however it's available from the SDK audio suites," meaning direct audio buffer access requires using the C++ SDK rather than ExtendScript.

### Project Item Audio Levels
"Project items (things in bins) have only their intrinsic audio levels, which aren't modifiable. Are you hoping instead to adjust/control the volume of clips in sequences?"

### Resources
- The PProPanel sample exercises Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API: https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/tree/master/PProPanel.
- As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

The `getAudioChannelMapping` functionality is available through the `audioChannelMapping` property on ProjectItem objects, but direct audio data/buffer access is not available via ExtendScript and would require the native C++ SDK.

Based on the search results, here's information about Premiere Pro UXP `executeTransaction` and `lockedAccess` for working with markers:

## Overview

`lockedAccess` gets a read/upgrade locked access to Project, where the project state will not change during the execution of the callback function. You can call `executeTransaction` while having locked access.

## Key API Methods

From the TypeScript definitions:

`executeTransaction(callback: (compoundAction: CompoundAction) => void, undoString?: string): boolean` executes an undoable transaction by passing a compound action. `lockedAccess(callback: () => void): void` gets a read/upgrade locked access to Project, and you can call executeTransaction while having locked access.

### Marker-Related Actions

`getMarkers(markerOwnerObject: Sequence | ClipProjectItem)` returns the Markers object for Sequence or ProjectItem. `createMoveMarkerAction(marker: Marker, tickTime: TickTime)` moves a marker to a new time value. `createAddMarkerAction(Name: string, markerType?: string, startTime?: TickTime, duration?: TickTime, comments?: string)` adds a new marker.(no content)Additional marker actions include `createSetColorByIndexAction(colorIndex: number)` to set the marker color, `createSetNameAction(name: string)` to set the name, `createSetDurationAction(tickTime: TickTime)` to set the duration, `createSetTypeAction(markerType: string)` to set the type, and `createSetCommentsAction(comments: string)` to set the comments.

## Community Insights

`lockedAccess` and `executeTransaction` did the trick for users who were having issues. One user was trying to use the `createAddMarkerAction` action and was following the documentation correctly in terms of setting up the function itself.

## Resources

- Instructions for developing UXP plugins within Premiere Pro are available. As of August 2025, only Premiere Pro BETA builds support UXP plugins. The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.

- Adobe provides a third-party sample panel in the premiere-api directory from the Git repository. You can build it by opening your console/terminal into sample-panels/premiere-api/html.

The pattern for using these APIs typically involves wrapping your marker operations inside `lockedAccess`, then using `executeTransaction` to perform undoable actions with the marker action methods.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

input.prompt: Extract the solution or workaround for accessing audio buffer/data from Premiere Pro clips. What methods are available for getting raw audio samples?
Extract code examples for: 1) setting clip colors/labels, 2) adding markers, 3) exporting audio. Look for any methods related to audio access or manipulation.

content.content: Prompt is too long

# Audio Buffer Access in Premiere Pro

Based on the Adobe community discussion provided, **there is no direct solution available** for extracting audio buffers from Premiere Pro clips via ExtendScript.

## Key Finding

The Adobe employee response explicitly states: "That approach will never work. 🙂"

The user attempted to access audio data through the SDK's BasicExternalObject example, hoping to call functions from a C++ DLL to retrieve audio buffers without pre-rendering. However, this workaround is not viable.

## Current Workaround

The only documented method requires:
1. **Pre-render the audio** to an MP3 or other format file
2. **Import the rendered file** into the CEP panel extension
3. **Process using Web Audio API** for analysis and editing

## Limitations

Premiere Pro's ExtendScript does not expose raw audio channel data directly. While the SDK contains audio processing capabilities, they are not accessible through the standard plugin entry points that ExtendScript can interact with.

**Recommendation:** Contact Adobe directly through the provided email (bbb@adobe.com) to describe your specific workflow needs for potential alternative solutions.

Here's information about using `setColorLabel` with projectItems in Premiere Pro ExtendScript:

## setColorLabel() Method

The syntax is `app.project.rootItem.children[index].setColorLabel(labelColor)` which sets the project item's color label.

### Example Code from Adobe's Official PProPanel Sample

From the Adobe-CEP Samples repository, here's a working example of the `changeLabel` function:

```javascript
changeLabel : function () {
    var first = app.project.rootItem.children[0];
    if (first) {
        var currentLabel = first.getColorLabel();
        var newLabel = currentLabel + 1; // 4 = Cerulean
```

The label color values range from 0 = Violet to 15 = Yellow.

```javascript
        if (newLabel > 15) {
            newLabel = newLabel - 16;
        }
        first.setColorLabel(newLabel);
    }
}
```

### Key Points

1. For projectItems, you can use `getColorLabel()` / `setColorLabel()`. Note: trackItems created from a projectItem will not have their label color updated; any new trackItems created from those projectItems, will get the updated label.

2. One can only change the label color of projectItems; there's no API to do so, for trackItems.

3. `getColorLabel()` retrieves the project item's color label.

### Label Color Values

The label color parameter is an integer from 0-15:
- 0 = Violet
- 4 = Cerulean
- 15 = Yellow

### Resources

- As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

- Official documentation: https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/item/projectitem/
- Sample panel code: https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/blob/master/PProPanel/jsx/PPRO/Premiere.jsx

Based on my search, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP with `require('premierepro')` for working with markers and labels:

## Accessing the Premiere Pro API

"The entry point to Premiere APIs is the app object, that you require() from the 'premierepro' module."(no content)The following line allows you access to the Premiere DOM via UXP. From here, you can open documents, modify them, run menu items, and more.

```javascript
const { app } = require("premierepro");
```

## Working with Markers

The Premiere APIs allow you to access and modify projects — sequences, tracks, clips, and markers.(no content)The Markers object returns the Markers object for Sequence or ProjectItem and can move the given marker at new time value.

### Creating Markers

From the TypeScript definitions, you can use `createAddMarkerAction(Name: string, markerType?: string, startTime?: TickTime, duration?: TickTime, comments?: string): Action` to add a new marker.

### Marker Color/Labels

You can use `createSetColorByIndexAction(colorIndex: number): Action` to return an action to set the color of the marker by the color index.

## Working with Color Labels on Project Items

`createSetColorLabelAction(inColorLabelIndex: number): Action` creates an action for setting a color label to a projectItem by index.(no content)You can use `getColorLabelIndex(): Promise<number>` to get the color label index of a projectItem.

## Important Notes

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, meaning they blocked the Premiere UI while they were executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous, and does not block the UI thread.(no content)In PPro, all markers and metadata associated with trackItems are actually attached to the backing projectItem; it's not possible to have different markers and metadata for each trackItem.

## Resources

- Sample plugins and instructions for developing UXP plugins are available at the GitHub repository, with documentation at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.
- As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported through September 2026.
